Award.AwardTitle: Models of the Photosynthetic Oxygen-Evolving Complex
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor George Christou of the University of Florida synthesizes and studies compounds related to the oxygen-evolving complex (OEC). The OEC is found in plants and certain bacteria, and for over 2Â½ billion years has been converting water to oxygen gas using sunlight as an energy source. Hence the OEC is responsible for the production and maintenance of the atmospheric oxygen on which all respiring life depends. The OEC is too fragile to be isolated from natural sources; therefore researchers are seeking to synthesize the OEC in the laboratory to study its properties and how it makes oxygen. The Christou lab will synthesize model compounds for OEC and study their ability to catalyze conversion of water to oxygen. This research has broader impacts on current efforts to harness and store solar energy. It also creates opportunities for graduate students to acquire advanced training in synthesis and specialized techniques such as magnetochemistry and electrocatalysis of water oxidation.

The goal of the research is to synthesize and study Mn4Ca/oxo clusters as models of the OEC, using recently developed methodologies to make mixed Mn/Ca cubane compounds. Derivatives with chelate-induced, structural perturbations that mimic the effect of the peptide scaffold on the OEC will be synthesized, as will be derivatives with manganese in different oxidation states and with strontium instead of calcium, Sr being the only metal that can replace Ca in OEC with retention of significant activity. The characterization of the compounds by magnetic measurements, and by EPR and X-ray spectroscopy will provide benchmarks useful in the study of OEC. The proposed work will enable the testing of current hypotheses about the precise level of structural distortion of the OEC and its influence on the properties of OEC, about whether the Sr-substituted OEC is isostructural with the Ca form, and about the origin of the distinctly different, electronic properties of the OEC at a given oxidation level and depending on generation conditions. The OEC models and other synthetic Mn compounds will also be explored as functional models, namely as electrocatalysts for water oxidation to oxygen, building on the discovery of such activity with low overpotential by certain Mn carboxylate clusters.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of the research were the preparation and study of inorganic compounds as models of the oxygen-evolving complex (OEC) of plants and cyanobacteria. The OEC is a {Mn4CaO5} unit attached primarily to protein carboxylate side-chains, and it catalyzes the oxidation of water to O2 during photosynthesis. The {Mn4CaO5} unit comprises a {Mn3CaO4} distorted cube with another Mn attached on the outside, and several groups, including the P.I.’s, had already developed synthetic routes to {Mn4CaO.}. Therefore, under CHE-1410394 support, the main emphasis was on developing Mn-based compounds, structurally similar to the OEC or not, that are functional models of the OEC, i.e., that could catalyze water oxidation to O2 gas. Efforts were thus concentrated on the [Mn12O12(O2CR)16(H2O)4] (8MnIII, 4MnIV; R = 3,5-dihydroxybenzoate) cluster, henceforth Mn12-dhb. This is soluble and stable in water, undergoes multiple reversible one-electron redox processes, both in the oxidizing and reducing directions, and possesses carboxylate ligands like the OEC, and four water binding sites.

Investigation of the electrochemistry of Mn12-dhb in aqueous buffer at pH=6 revealed two one-electron oxidations in scans up to +1.8 V vs NHE, and on reversing the scan the characteristic feature of O2 reduction to superoxide (O2?) appeared, indicating that oxidation of Mn12-dhb triggers oxidation of water to O2. Subsequent studies showed that only scanning through the first oxidation was necessary to produce O2, representing water oxidation to O2 with a remarkably small over-potential of only 0.33 V. At a fixed potential of 1.21 V, Mn12-dhb acts as an efficient electro-catalyst of water oxidation for some 5 h before the activity dies off, presumably due to compound degradation.  Thus, to potentially increase catalyst stability under the reaction conditions, synthetic methods were developed to two other families of potential catalysts, mixed Mn/CoIII-oxo and CoII,III-oxo carboxylate clusters, to take advantage of the known inertness and robustness of octahedral CoIII-containing compounds. Specifically, these methods led to novel families of CoIII6MnIV5 and CoIII4CoIIx (x = 2-4) clusters being attained and studied, establishing that they function as water oxidation electrocatalysts that are stable for longer times than Mn12, as hoped, but with slightly higher over-potentials. This shows that the approach can feasibly lead, on further refinements of structural aspects, Co:Mn ratios, and redox potentials in future work, to improved catalysts with optimized activity and reduced over-potentials.  

The P.I. and his group carried out a range of broader impact activities throughout the funding period, spanning education, domestic and international conference organization, and outreach: (a) The P.I.’s group supported the planning and execution of the chemistry demonstrations and other activities in the annual Chemistry Day at the Mall in Gainesville, FL, targeted at K-12 students, their teachers and parents, and the local community and media. These events are directed at increasing public awareness of the impact of chemistry in our daily lives, and to foster greater awareness and interactions between the chemistry department and the local community. The event was always a great community and media success; (b) The P.I. had an undergraduate in his group at all times getting research experience; (c) The P.I.’s group assisted synthetic chemists at overseas institutions in the characterization of their materials via magnetic studies using the SQUID magnetometer; (d) The P.I. organized every year the Showcase Symposium, which he founded in 2012, at the annual meeting of the ACS Florida Section, designed to showcase senior scientists and educators in the state of Florida, and foster increased interactions among Florida colleges and universities; (e) The P.I. also organized the annual Florida Inorganic and Materials Symposium (FIMS) student meetings of Florida higher education institutions spanning fourteen undergraduate and PhD granting universities, including the historically black Florida A&M University; only undergraduate and graduate students may give oral presentations, one per group; (f)  The P.I. co-organized two international workshops, the Current Trends in Molecular and Nanoscale Magnetism (CTMNM) meeting (Pylos, Greece, 2016, Sparta, Greece 2018), a specialized magnetism workshop spanning chemistry and physics, and the broad North America-Greece-Cyprus Workshop on Paramagnetic Materials (NAGC) (Athens, Greece, 2015, and Paphos, Cyprus, 2017) spanning chemistry, physics and materials science. Both the CTMNM and NAGC workshops included many oral presentations from students and postdoctorals, including students from the P.I.’s group.

 


Last Modified: 09/05/2018
Modified by: George Christou
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The goals of the research were the preparation and study of inorganic compounds as models of the oxygen-evolving complex (OEC) of plants and cyanobacteria. The OEC is a {Mn4CaO5} unit attached primarily to protein carboxylate side-chains, and it catalyzes the oxidation of water to O2 during photosynthesis. The {Mn4CaO5} unit comprises a {Mn3CaO4} distorted cube with another Mn attached on the outside, and several groups, including the P.I.?s, had already developed synthetic routes to {Mn4CaO.}. Therefore, under CHE-1410394 support, the main emphasis was on developing Mn-based compounds, structurally similar to the OEC or not, that are functional models of the OEC, i.e., that could catalyze water oxidation to O2 gas. Efforts were thus concentrated on the [Mn12O12(O2CR)16(H2O)4] (8MnIII, 4MnIV; R = 3,5-dihydroxybenzoate) cluster, henceforth Mn12-dhb. This is soluble and stable in water, undergoes multiple reversible one-electron redox processes, both in the oxidizing and reducing directions, and possesses carboxylate ligands like the OEC, and four water binding sites. Investigation of the electrochemistry of Mn12-dhb in aqueous buffer at pH=6 revealed two one-electron oxidations in scans up to +1.8 V vs NHE, and on reversing the scan the characteristic feature of O2 reduction to superoxide (O2?) appeared, indicating that oxidation of Mn12-dhb triggers oxidation of water to O2. Subsequent studies showed that only scanning through the first oxidation was necessary to produce O2, representing water oxidation to O2 with a remarkably small over-potential of only 0.33 V. At a fixed potential of 1.21 V, Mn12-dhb acts as an efficient electro-catalyst of water oxidation for some 5 h before the activity dies off, presumably due to compound degradation. Thus, to potentially increase catalyst stability under the reaction conditions, synthetic methods were developed to two other families of potential catalysts, mixed Mn/CoIII-oxo and CoII,III-oxo carboxylate clusters, to take advantage of the known inertness and robustness of octahedral CoIII-containing compounds. These events are directed at increasing public awareness of the impact of chemistry in our daily lives, and to foster greater awareness and interactions between the chemistry department and the local community. The event was always a great community and media success; (b) The P.I. had an undergraduate in his group at all times getting research experience; (c) The P.I.?s group assisted synthetic chemists at overseas institutions in the characterization of their materials via magnetic studies using the SQUID magnetometer; (d) The P.I. organized every year the Showcase Symposium, which he founded in 2012, at the annual meeting of the ACS Florida Section, designed to showcase senior scientists and educators in the state of Florida, and foster increased interactions among Florida colleges and universities; (e) The P.I. also organized the annual Florida Inorganic and Materials Symposium (FIMS) student meetings of Florida higher education institutions spanning fourteen undergraduate and PhD granting universities, including the historically black Florida A&M University; only undergraduate and graduate students may give oral presentations, one per group; (f) The P.I. co-organized two international workshops, the Current Trends in Molecular and Nanoscale Magnetism (CTMNM) meeting (Pylos, Greece, 2016, Sparta, Greece 2018), a specialized magnetism workshop spanning chemistry and physics, and the broad North America-Greece-Cyprus Workshop on Paramagnetic Materials (NAGC) (Athens, Greece, 2015, and Paphos, Cyprus, 2017) spanning chemistry, physics and materials science.
